Label: date: Start Date
date_end: End Date
status_response: Response Type
ip: IP Address
progress: Progress
time: Duration (in seconds)
terminated: Finished

ID_qualtrics: Response ID
name: Recipient Last Name
firstname: Recipient First Name
mmail: Recipient Email
ref: External Data Reference
lat: Location Latitude
long: Location Longitude
distr: Distribution Channel
lang: User Language
gender: What is your gender?
age_exact: How old are you?
zipcode: What is your ZIP code?
couple: Do you live with your partner (if you have one)?

hh_size: How many people are in your household? 
The household includes: you, the members of your family who live with you, and your dependents.
race_white: What race or ethnicity do you identify with? (Multiple answers are possible) - White
race_black: What race or ethnicity do you identify with? (Multiple answers are possible) - Black or African American
race_hispanic: What race or ethnicity do you identify with? (Multiple answers are possible) - Hispanic
race_asian: What race or ethnicity do you identify with? (Multiple answers are possible) - Asian
race_native: What race or ethnicity do you identify with? (Multiple answers are possible) - American Indian or Alaskan Native
race_hawaii: What race or ethnicity do you identify with? (Multiple answers are possible) - Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander
race_other: What race or ethnicity do you identify with? (Multiple answers are possible) - Other
race_pnr: What race or ethnicity do you identify with? (Multiple answers are possible) - Prefer not to say

income: What is the annual gross income of your household (before taxes)?

This includes all income: wages, self-employment earnings, Social Security benefits, pensions, investment income, welfare payments, and income from other sources.

education: What is the highest level of education you have completed? /! For EU, the values don't correspond to the responses. To see the correspondence between values and responses in each country, cf. specificities.xlsx$Education
employment_status: What is your employment status?
Levels: Full-time employed / Inactive / Retired / Self-employed / Unemployed / Student / Part-time employed

Label: home_tenant: Are you a homeowner or a tenant? (Multiple answers are possible) - Tenant
home_owner: Are you a homeowner or a tenant? (Multiple answers are possible) - Owner
home_landlord: Are you a homeowner or a tenant? (Multiple answers are possible) - Landlord renting out property
home_hosted: Are you a homeowner or a tenant? (Multiple answers are possible) - Hosted free of charge

wealth_couple: What is the estimated value of your household's assets (in U.S. dollars)? (note that you don't have to answer that question.)

 

Include here all your possessions (home, car, savings, etc.) net of debt. For example, if you own a house worth $300,000 and you have $100,000 left to repay on your mortgage, your assets are $200,000.

 
I estimate my household's assets net of debt to be:
Levels: Between $120,000 and $380,000 / More than $380,000 / NA / Between $4,000 and $120,000 / Less than $0 (I have a net debt) / Close to $0

Label:
wealth_single: What
is the estimated value of your assets (in U.S. dollars)?  (note that you don't have to answer that question.)

Include here all your possessions (home, car, savings, etc.) net of debt. For example, if you own a house worth $300,000 and you have $100,000 left to repay on your mortgage, your assets are $200,000.
I estimate my assets net of debt to be:
Levels: NA / Between $60,000 and $190,000 / Close to $0 / More than $190,000 / Between $4,000 and $60,000 / Less than $0 (I have a net debt)

gcs_win_lose: Who would win or lose financially in the Global climate scheme?

Levels: Typical win, richest lose / Typical lose, richest win / Typical win, richest win / Typical lose, richest lose

attention_test: Please select "A little" (this is a test to see if you are paying attention).

petition_gcs: Would you be willing to sign a petition for the Global climate scheme? 

As soon as the survey is complete, we will send the results to the U.S. President's office, informing him what share of American people are willing to endorse the Global climate scheme. (You will NOT be asked to sign, only your answer here is required and remains anonymous.)
donation_charities: How much did you give to charities in 2022?
Levels: Between $1,001 and $5,000. / Between $501 and $1,000. / Less than $100. / I did not make donations to charities last year. / Between $101 and $500. / More than $5,000.

Label: interested_politics: To what extent are you interested in politics?
Levels: A lot / Moderately / A little / A great deal / Not at all

Label: involvement_govt: Where would you rate yourself on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 means you think the government should do only those things necessary to provide the most basic government functions, and 5 means you think the government should take active steps in every area it can to try and improve the lives of its citizens? - Desired involvement of government

left_right: On economic policy matters, where do you see yourself on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is Left (favoring equality and government interventions) and 5 is Right (favoring free competition and little government intervention)? - Left (1) to Right (5) on economic issues
vote_participation: Did you vote in the 2020 U.S. presidential election?
Levels: No right to vote / Yes / Prefer not to say / No

points_econ1: In this question, you have 100 points that you can allocate to different policies. The more you give points to a policy, the more you support it.

 

How do you allocate the points among the following policies?

 

You can adjust the number of points either using the slider or entering the number of your choice on the right-hand-side. The sum of points must equal exactly 100. By pushing the last slider to the right, the total will automatically adjust to 100. Please read the 6 options before making your choice. - Student loan forgiveness

urban_category: [1-4] Computed from the zipcode. NA indicates an unrecognized zipcode. For FR/DE/ES, Eurostat's degree of urbanization (1: Cities, 2: Towns and suburbs, 3: Rural). For the UK we use another classification that tends to classify zipcodes as more rural than Eurostat (cf. zipcodes.R). For the US, recoded from RUCA codes (1: Metropolitan core (RUCA 1, 73% pop), 2: Metro non-core (2-3), 3: Micropolitan or Small town (< 50k, 4-9), 4: Rural (10)).

branch_petition: gcs/nr Whether the petition question is on the global climate scheme or national redistribution.
petition: Yes/No Willing to sign a petition on gcs/nr (depends on branch_petition).
age_exact: How old are you?
race: White only/Hispanic/Black/Other. True proportions: .601/.185/.134/.08

income: What is the annual gross income of your household (before taxes)?

This includes all income: wages, self-employment earnings, Social Security benefits, pensions, investment income, welfare payments, and income from other sources.
Levels: between $42,001 and $50,000 / between $103,001 and $130,000 / between $20,001 and $35,000 / between $65,001 and $82,000 / between $35,001 and $42,000 / between $165,000 and $250,000 / less than $20,000 / between $145,001 and $165,000 / between $82,001 and $103,000 / between $130,001 and $145,000 / between $50,001 and $65,000 / I prefer not to answer

Label: income_decile: [1-10] Decile of income. For US, this is total household income and for EU, equivalised disposable income (i.e. total income divided by the household's number of consumption units).
income_quartile: [1-4] Quartile of income. For US, this is total household income and for EU, equivalised disposable income (i.e. total income divided by the household's number of consumption units).

income_factor: 1/2/3/4 Quartile of income, as a factor rather than a numeric vector. For US, this is total household income and for EU, equivalised disposable income (i.e. total income divided by the household's number of consumption units).
urbanity: 1: Cities / 2: Towns and suburbs / 3: Rural. Computed from the zipcode. For EU, equals urban_category; for the U.S., urbanity = 1; 2; 3 (resp.) corresponds to urban_category = 1; 2 or 3; 4.
urban: T/F urban_category == 1: Cities (EU) or Core metropolitan (US).
education: What is the highest level of education you have completed?
Levels: Bachelor's degree (for example: BA, BS) / Regular high school diploma/GED or alternative credential / 2-year college degree or associates degree (for example: AA, AS) / Some college, no degree / Masterâ€™s degree or above (MA, MS, MEng, MEd, MSW, MBA, MD, DDS, DVM, LLB, JD, PhD) / Some high school / Eigth grade

Label: diploma: 1: Below upper secondary (ISCED 0-2) / 2: Upper secondary (ISCED 3) / 3: Post secondary (ISCED 4-8), recoded from education.
Levels: Below upper secondary: 1 / Upper secondary: 2 / Post secondary: 3

Label: diploma_25_64: 0: Not 25-64 if age is not within 25-64 (missing value) / 1: Below upper secondary (ISCED 0-2) / 2: Upper secondary (ISCED 3) / 3: Post secondary (ISCED 4-8), recoded from education.
Levels: Not 25-64: 0 / Below upper secondary: 1 / Upper secondary: 2 / Post secondary: 3

Label: employment: T/F/NA indicator that the respondent is employed (employment_agg == Working), NA if s-he is above 65.
wealth: Quintile of wealth (from wealth_couple and wealth_single).
owner: Owner or Landlord renting out property to: Are you a homeowner or a tenant?

branch_list_exp: i/ir/gr/igr Variant of the list experiment faced, where i denotes coal exit (US) or the buildings' insulation plan (EU), r the national redistribution, and g the global climate scheme. Marriage only for opposite-sex couples (US) and death penalty for major crimes (EU) were also systematically included.
branch_list_exp_g: T/F g (global climate scheme) is present in the list experiment.
branch_list_exp_r: T/F r (national redistribution) is present in the list experiment.
list_exp: [0-4] Number of supported policies in the list experiment (combining all branches, cf. branch_list_exp and variables_list_exp).
gcs_win_lose: Who would win or lose financially in the Global climate scheme?
Levels: Typical Americans would lose and the 700 million poorest humans would win. / Typical Americans would win and the 700 million poorest humans would lose. / Typical Americans would lose and the 700 million poorest humans would lose. / Typical Americans would win and the 700 million poorest humans would win.

Label: nr_win_lose: Who would win or lose financially in the National redistribution scheme?
Levels: Typical Americans would win and the richest Americans would lose. / Typical Americans would lose and the richest Americans would win. / Typical Americans would win and the richest Americans would win. / Typical Americans would lose and the richest Americans would lose.

Label: both_win_lose: If both the Global climate scheme and the National redistribution scheme are implemented, how would a typical American be financially affected?
Levels: A typical American would lose out financially. / A typical American would neither gain nor lose. / A typical American would gain financially.

Label: nr_understood: T/F Correct answer to nr_win_lose (in national redistribution, typical people win, richest lose).
gcs_understood: T/F Correct answer to gcs_win_lose (in global climate scheme, typical high-income win, 700M poorest lose).
both_understood: T/F Correct answer to both_win_lose (in national redistribution + global climate scheme combined, typical people in high-income countries are unaffected).
score_understood: [0-3] Number correct answers to understanding questions (nr/gcs/both_understood).
z_score_understood: Normalized score_understood.
conjoint_a: T/F Bundle with GCS is chosen in conjoint analysis (a), i.e. irg > ir.
conjoint_b: T/F Bundle with GCS is chosen in conjoint analysis (b) when GCS is in one Bundle, or ir > r in case GCS is in no bundle.
branch_conjoint_b: ir_gr/r_igr/gr_r/ir_r Random branch faced by the respondent in conjoint analysis (b).
conjoint_c: T/F Left-wing candidate is chosen in conjoint_c (cf. branch_c_gcs to know whether the Left candidate includes GCS in their platform).
branch_conjoint_c: left_right/leftg_right Random branch faced by the respondent in conjoint analysis (c), used in branch_c_gcs := branch_conjoint_c == 'leftg_right.'
conjoint_d: T/F Candidate with GCS is chosen in conjoint analysis (d). In US1, question asked only to non-Republican.
branch_b_gcs: T/F Whether GCS is in one Bundle in conjoint_b, i.e. =F iff branch_conjoint_b == 'conjoint_rc_r'.
conjoint_b_na: T/F/NA Bundle with GCS is chosen in conjoint analysis (b) when GCS is in one Bundle, NA in case GCS is in no bundle (i.e. branch_b_gcs == F i.e. branch_conjoint_b == 'conjoint_rc_r'.
branch_c_gcs: T/F Whether GCS is in the Left-wing platform in conjoint_c, i.e. =T iff branch_conjoint_c == 'conjoint_leftg_right'.
conjoint_r_type: None/A/B/Both Which candidate includes GCS in their program in conjoint_left_a_b
conjoint_r: T/F/NA Whether the candidate who includes GCS in their program is preferred (NA if both or none include GCS). In US1, question asked only to non-Republican.

Label: conjoint_r_number: 1/2/NA (instead of A/B) Candidate with GCS is chosen in conjoint analysis (r). In US1, question asked only to non-Republican. NA if question not asked or there is some unrecognized level (conjoint_r_wrong_level == T).
vote: What the respondent has voted or would have voted in the last election, combining vote_[country]_voters and vote_[country]_non_voters.
Levels: Biden / Hawkins / Prefer not to say / Trump / Jorgensen

Label: vote_agg: What the respondent has voted or would have voted in the last election, lumping minor candidates (with less than 5% of $vote) into 'Other'. Build from $vote that combines $vote_[country]_voters and $vote_[country]_non_voters.
Levels: Biden / Other / Prefer not to say / Trump

Label: voted: Has voted in last election: Yes to vote_participation.
survey_biased_yes: T/F Finds the survey biased (survey_biased != No)
survey_biased_left: T/F Finds the survey left-wing biased (survey_biased == Yes, left)
survey_biased_right: T/F Finds the survey right-wing biased (survey_biased == Yes, right)
petition_matches_support: T/F The answer to the petition coincides with the answer to the support (cf. branch_petition to see which measure: gcs/nr).
petition_yes_support_no: T/F Willing to sign the petition but does not support (cf. branch_petition to see which measure: gcs/nr).
petition_no_support_yes: T/F Not willing to sign the petition but supports (cf. branch_petition to see which measure: gcs/nr).
conjoint_a_matches_support: T/F The answer to conjoint analysis (a) (irg vs. ir) corresponds to the answer to the support of GCS.
conjoint_a_irg_support_no: T/F Prefers irg to ir in conjoint analysis (a) but does not support GCS.
conjoint_a_ir_support_yes: T/F Prefers ir to irg in conjoint analysis (a) but supports GCS.
share_policies_supported: Share of all policies supported (strongly or somewhat) among all policies asked to the respondent.
spread_problem: Spread between max and min value in the respondent's answers to the matrix problem
all_same_problem: T/F Indicator that all answers to the matrix problem are identical.
mean_spread: Mean spread between max and min value in the respondent's answers to the matrices (averaged over the matrices: problem). -Inf indicates that all answers were NA.
mean_spread: Share of matrices to which all respondent's answers are identical (among matrices: problem).
wrong_language: T/F The language does not correspond to the respondent's country (including Spanish in the U.S.).
number_same_ip: Number of respondents with the same IP.
duplicate_ip: T/F The respondent's IP is used by other respondents.
valid: Respondents that has not been screened out due to speed or failure to the attention test.
dropout: Respondent who did not complete the survey though was not excluded.
finished_attentive: Respondent completed the survey and did not fail the attention test.
